text.p: Here are highlights from Polish newspapers on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
POLITICAL NEWS DZIENNIK PRAWA I GOSPODARKI

- The co-ruling Polish Peasants Party (PSL) has demanded dismissal of Prime Minister Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz of the ex-communist Democratic Left Alliance (SLD) over his agricultural policy. RZECZPOSPOLITA

- Poland's Senate has axed a chapter on property declarations from the new tax law proposed by the parliament's lower chamber, the Sejm. The removed regulations would have forced taxpayers describe their property if its value exceeded 500,000 zlotys. ECONOMIC AND MARKET STORIES RZECZPOSPOLITA

- Poland's current account deficit reached nearly $7 billion in the first half of 1997, 10 times more than in the corresponding period last year, the National Bank of Poland (NBP), the central bank said.

- The general shareholders meeting of the state-owned PZU insurance firm approved a new share issue to increase the firm's share capital by between 19 and 34 percent. A U.S. investor representing the insurance sector has expressed interest in buying into Poland's biggest insurance firm, but PZU declined to disclose its name.

- Telekomunikacja Polska SA (TPSA), the state-owned telecoms monopolist, will build a high-tech international telephone exchange in Poznan, western Poland, worth 3.5 million European Currency Units (ECU) in 10 months.

- The Polish State Railways (PKP) has already reintroduced most train connections on the Wroclaw and Opole route, which pass the regions of south-western Poland, heavily struck by recent floods. - Around 1,500 firms will exhibit at Poland's biggest consumer goods' fair in Poznan, western Poland, to start on September 2, the fair organiser said.
- ABB Beeiligungen has bought an 80 percent stake in the ZWAR electrical engineering firm, ABB said. The companies declined to disclose the value of the contract.

- The U.S.'s CPC concern will invest up to $42 million in development of its Polish subsidiary, the Amino food concentrate maker, which is over 200 percent more than the initially declared volume of investments, CPC Amino general director Jacek Liczkowski said.
- Poland's finance ministry has approved the purchase of the STU life and non-life insurance firms by Cigna International insurance group. DZIENNIK PRAWA I GOSPODARKI
- The Lubiana china-maker controlled by the National Investment Fund (NFI) No. 3 plans a share listing on the Warsaw bourse in the first quarter of 1998, Lubiana's president Benon Mahlik said.
- The Czech Union Banka bought a 70 percent stake in small Bank Przemyslowy of Lodz, central Poland, worth 37.2 million zlotys, Przemyslowy's president Jerzy Fornalczyk said.
- Poland's urban transport firms bought 637 buses in the first half of 1997, most of which were produced by the Jelcz, Ikarus, Neoplan, Scania and Volvo bus-makers.
